buyerGroup.name: Albert Vilar Mateu
buyerGroup.title: Vice President Operations
buyerGroup.aiReasoning: Albert Vilar Mateu is a VP of Operations at a 100-employee software company. While he holds a VP-level position indicating senior decision-making authority, his department (Operations) is not the primary user or owner of Sales Intelligence Software. Operations VPs typically focus on operational efficiency, supply chain, production, or service delivery rather than sales processes. However, there are several considerations that prevent complete exclusion: (1) At a 100-person company, VPs often have cross-functional influence and may participate in strategic purchasing decisions, especially for significant investments like $150K; (2) Operations may have tangential interest in sales intelligence if it impacts forecasting, resource planning, or operational capacity; (3) He could be involved in vendor evaluation processes or budget approval committees. The primary buyers would typically be the VP/Head of Sales, CRO, or Revenue Operations leaders. Albert's role would more likely be as a peripheral stakeholder who might provide input on operational integration or be consulted on company-wide strategic purchases, rather than being a champion or primary decision-maker. His influence is moderate (4/10) due to his VP-level seniority but limited by the lack of direct ownership of the sales function.
buyerGroup.roleReasoning: Promoted to decision maker (no better candidate found)

aiRoleValidation.reasoning: Albert Vilar Mateu should retain the 'decision' role based on several strong factors: (1) As VP of Operations at a software company, he holds clear budget authority for a $150K investment, which falls within typical VP-level approval thresholds. (2) Sales Intelligence Software directly impacts operational efficiency, pipeline management, and revenue operations - all within his operational purview. (3) His seniority as VP indicates he has P&L responsibility and final sign-off authority. (4) The existing buyer group composition shows Le Linh as champion (likely an operational leader advocating for the solution), which creates a logical dynamic where the champion drives internal advocacy while the VP provides ultimate approval. (5) At NedGraphics Software, a VP Operations would typically own sales enablement tools and customer-facing operational systems. (6) The $150K deal size requires executive-level approval but isn't large enough to necessarily escalate to C-suite, making VP the appropriate decision-maker. The role is already correctly assigned.

(5) At NedGraphics Software, a VP Operations would typically own sales enablement tools and customer-facing operational systems. (6) The $150K deal size requires executive-level approval but isn't large enough to necessarily escalate to C-suite, making VP the appropriate decision-maker. The role is already correctly assigned.

fullProfile.headline: Vice President of Operations at Nedgraphics and Optitex
fullProfile.summary: As an accomplished Business Director with over 20 years of experience leading high-performing teams and enterprise-wide complex business units, I am proud of my demonstrated ability to lead Global Operations and cross-functional Project Management Offices. These projects advance businesses and the customers they serve. In addition, I bring a deep expertise in process management, people management, operations, and project management. Over the years, leaders, clients, and peers have recognized my ability to limit risk, create lean teams, and optimize operations between financial returns and exceptional employee and customer experiences.

recommendations.recommendation: ‚ÄúAlbert was my classmate at the Executive MBA we have just finished recently. I can definitely say that he is one of the most outstanding people I've met during the master. He has a lot of valuable skills, which make him a great and very responsible professional with whom I would love to work at any time. He does not only have a lot of knowledge generally about business, economics, finance and project/program/portfolio management, but he is a great leader and I would say a very creative person as well. He is always proactive, extremely sociable and always keen on help anybody and share his knowledge with others. Without any doubt I would recommend him for any management position, I do believe he has all the skills to lead and even to create a great team from scratch. It was a pleasure to work with Albert during the master in lot of different projects and I personally learned a lot from him.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlbert demostr√≥ en su etapa en Inca Ingenier√≠a ser una persona extremadamente responsable y profesional, proporcionando al departamento el valor a√±adido y el impulso que necesitaba. Capaz de asumir los retos que se proponga, mi experiencia de tenerle como colaborador durante m√°s de dos a√±os fue plenamente satisfactoria y acorde con el nivel que demuestra su perfil.‚Äù

buyerGroup.name: Le Linh
buyerGroup.title: Sales Manager
buyerGroup.company: Optitex | 3D Virtual Prototyping, 2D CAD/CAM Software Solutions
buyerGroup.aiReasoning: Le Linh is highly relevant for Sales Intelligence Software procurement. As Sales Manager at Optitex, they are directly in the sales department and would be a primary user and beneficiary of sales intelligence tools. Their role typically involves lead generation, account research, prospect targeting, and sales execution - all core use cases for sales intelligence software. With a $150K deal size and 100-employee company, this purchase would likely require C-level (VP Sales/CRO) final approval, but Le Linh would be a strong champion and influencer in the buying process. They would evaluate the tool's practical value, potentially run pilots, and advocate for adoption based on impact to their team's performance. Their 500+ LinkedIn connections suggest active networking and sales engagement, indicating they understand the value of intelligence tools. The influence score of 7 reflects meaningful input and evaluation authority, though likely not final budget approval at this deal size. No red flags present - title and department perfectly align with the product category.
buyerGroup.roleReasoning: Selected as Champion for advocacy and implementation: Manager-level leaders implement solutions and influence team adoption. Sales leaders are natural champions for revenue-generating tools. High champion potential based on role and department alignment.

aiRoleValidation.reasoning: Le Linh is already correctly assigned as champion. As Sales Manager at Optitex, she is the ideal champion for Sales Intelligence Software because: (1) Her department (Sales) is the primary end-user of this product and will directly benefit from sales intelligence capabilities, (2) Sales Managers typically drive the evaluation and selection of sales tools but rarely have budget authority for $150K purchases - that would sit with VP/Director level or above, (3) She has strong operational motivation to advocate for tools that will improve her team's performance and productivity, (4) At the Manager level in a software company, she likely lacks purchasing authority for six-figure deals but has significant influence over tool selection, (5) The buyer group already has Albert Vilar Mateu as the decision maker, which is appropriate hierarchy - Le Linh would champion the solution and Albert would approve the budget. Her role as champion is optimal because she combines direct product relevance, operational leadership, and internal advocacy capability without having final budget authority.

Her role as champion is optimal because she combines direct product relevance, operational leadership, and internal advocacy capability without having final budget authority.

report.executiveSummary: Identified 2-person buyer group for Optitex ($150,000 deal) with 66% cohesion score. Group includes 1 decision maker(s), 1 champion(s), and comprehensive cross-functional coverage. Research methodology validated 2 final members from 20 initial candidates.

stages.name: Company Intelligence
stages.description: Database-first company research with Coresignal API fallback

stages.name: Wide Preview Search
stages.description: Cross-departmental employee discovery using Coresignal Preview API

stages.name: Smart Scoring
stages.description: Multi-dimensional scoring: seniority, influence, champion potential, cross-functional ability
stages.result: Top candidates identified before expensive collect API

stages.name: Role Assignment
stages.description: Deal-size-aware role assignment ensuring Decision Maker + Champion
stages.result: Appropriate roles assigned based on deal size

stages.name: Cross-Functional Validation
stages.description: Stakeholder completeness validation across all relevant functions
stages.result: Missing stakeholders added for comprehensive coverage

stages.name: Full Profile Collection

stages.result: Complete profiles for final buyer group
